bioghist.p: The Massachusetts Steam Navigation Company was formed in 1816 and formally incorporated in 1817. The company financed the building of the steamboat Massachusetts in 1816 by William Dodge in Philadelphia. The steamboat made its appearance in Salem, Massachusetts, in June of 1817. The vessel was probably the first coastal steamer in the area of Boston and the adjacent north and south coasts. The Massachusetts apparently operated at a loss and was sold to Captain Charles Vanderford in November of 1817 and then to Francis H. Story later in the same month. It was wrecked off the coast of New Jersey on its way to Alabama in December 1817. In 1818, William Dodge requested permission to recover remains from the wreckage. It has been suggested, but not confirmed, that parts from the first Massachusetts were used in the construction of a later vessel of the same name. Joel and Isaac Newhall were among the subscribers of the Massachusetts Steam Navigation Company.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of the Massachusetts Steam Navigation Company, 1816-1818. Materials include correspondence and financial records. Correspondence details the financing and construction of the steamboat Massachusetts as well as engines and parts for several uncompleted vessels commissioned by the firm's shareholders. Other correspondence documents the active life of the Massachusetts, financing of the firm, discussions about repairs, and legal matters related to damages to the engine. Financial records include accounts of the MSNC, lists of investments and earnings of shareholders, and bills from individuals and firms who supplied goods and services for the Massachusetts.
